params.name: idempotencyKey
params.doc: Unique value generated by the client which the service uses to recognize subsequent retries of the same request

docs.summary:
Change balance using one of these operations:
ADJUST
SET
SET_INITIAL

examples.title: changeBalance example for dashboard page code
body: const result = await balance.changeBalance(poolId, idempotencyKey, options);

examples.title: changeBalance example for exporting from backend code
body: const result = await elevatedChangeBalance(poolId, idempotencyKey, options);

revertBalanceChange example for exporting from backend code

members.name: amount
members.doc: Change the available balance by the provided amount. Can be negative and positive values.

members.name: beneficiary
members.doc: Beneficiary of the operation

members.name: _createdDate
members.doc: Represents the time the transaction was created

members.name: _id
members.doc: The id of the balance. Same as the pool id

members.name: _updatedDate
members.doc: Represents the time the transaction was last updated

members.name: balance
members.doc: Balance for the pool

members.name: beneficiary
members.doc: The owner of this balance

members.name: extendedFields
members.doc: Data extensions

members.name: lastTransactionId
members.doc: Last transaction id, which triggered balance change

members.name: pool
members.doc: Pool information

members.name: revision
members.doc: Represents the current state of an item. Each time the item is modified, its `revision` changes. for an update operation to succeed, you MUST pass the latest revision

members.name: available
members.doc: Represents the sum of the available credits for the pool

members.name: originalTransactionId
members.doc: The id of the transaction which was already reverted

members.name: revertedTransactionId
members.doc: The id of the transaction which reverted the original transaction

members.name: adjustOptions
members.doc: Applies the delta to the current balance. If 0, change won't be performed, but the transaction is still going to be reported

members.name: instructingParty
members.doc: Party that initiated this change. Could be the site use, the pool owner or the beneficiary

members.name: setInitialOptions
members.doc:
Sets the initial balance to any amount. Initializes the pool account. Must be the first operation performed on the account and only called once
All subsequent SetInitialOperations will fail.

members.name: setOptions
members.doc: Sets the balance to any amount. If the set amount is the same as the current balance no action will be performed

members.name: transactionDetails
members.doc: Transaction details related to the change

members.name: type
members.doc: The operation to perform on the balance

members.name: adjustOptions
members.doc: Applies the delta to the current balance. If 0, change won't be performed, but the transaction is still going to be reported

members.name: transactionId

members.name: cursor
members.doc:
Pointer to the next or previous page in the list of results.

Pass the relevant cursor token from the `pagingMetadata` object in the previous call's response.
Not relevant for the first request.

members.name: limit
members.doc: Maximum number of items to return in the results.

members.name: count
members.doc: Number of items returned in the response.

members.name: cursors
members.doc: Cursor strings that point to the next page, previous page, or both.

members.name: hasNext
members.doc:
Whether there are more pages to retrieve following the current page.

+ `true`: Another page of results can be retrieved.
+ `false`: This is the last page.

members.name: cursorPaging
members.doc: Cursor token pointing to a page of results. Not used in the first request. Following requests use the cursor token and not `filter` or `sort`.

members.name: filter
sort
members.doc:
Sort object in the following format:
`[{"fieldName":"sortField1","order":"ASC"},{"fieldName":"sortField2","order":"DESC"}]`

members.name: cursorPaging
members.doc: Cursor token pointing to a page of results. Not used in the first request. Following requests use the cursor token and not `filter` or `sort`.

members.name: next
members.doc: Cursor string pointing to the next page in the list of results.

members.name: prev
members.doc: Cursor pointing to the previous page in the list of results.

members.name: _id
members.doc:
Unique event ID.
Allows clients to ignore duplicate webhooks.

members.name: entityEventSequence
members.doc:
A sequence number defining the order of updates to the underlying entity.
For example, given that some entity was updated at 16:00 and than again at 16:01,
it is guaranteed that the sequence number of the second update is strictly higher than the first.
As the consumer, you can use this value to ensure that you handle messages in the correct order.
To do so, you will need to persist this number on your end, and compare the sequence number from the
message against the one you have stored. Given that the stored number is higher, you should ignore the message.

members.name: entityFqdn
members.doc:
Assumes actions are also always typed to an entity_type
Example: wix.stores.catalog.product, wix.bookings.session, wix.payments.transaction

members.name: entityId
members.doc: ID of the entity associated with the event.

members.name: eventTime
members.doc: Event timestamp.

members.name: originatedFrom
members.doc: If present, indicates the action that triggered the event.

members.name: slug
members.doc:
This is top level to ease client code dispatching of messages (switch on entity_fqdn+slug)
This is although the created/updated/deleted notion is duplication of the oneof types
Example: created/updated/deleted/started/completed/email_opened

members.name: triggeredByAnonymizeRequest
members.doc:
Whether the event was triggered as a result of a privacy regulation application
(for example, GDPR).

members.name: deletedEntityAsJson
members.doc: Entity that was deleted

members.name: currentEntityAsJson
members.doc:
Since platformized APIs only expose PATCH and not PUT we can't assume that the fields sent from the client are the actual diff.
This means that to generate a list of changed fields (as opposed to sent fields) one needs to traverse both objects.
We don't want to impose this on all developers and so we leave this traversal to the notification recipients which need it.

members.name: namespaces
members.doc:
Extended field data. Each key corresponds to the namespace of the app that created the extended fields.
The value of each key is structured according to the schema defined when the extended fields were configured.

You can only access fields for which you have the appropriate permissions.

Learn more about [extended fields](https://dev.wix.com/docs/rest/articles/getting-started/extended-fields).
